docs.lead_paragraph: IF Timothy Fink has a pet peeve about running a pipe organ company, it is spending tens of thousands of dollars to train employees only to have them leave. That, and being greeted by church secretaries with, ''the piano man is here.'' Mr. Fink, 39, who started Timothy Fink & Company in Port Chester, N.Y., in 1997 after working in the organ building field for 19 years, views labor turnover as an anticipated cost. ''I think everyone finds out when you start to run a business,'' he said, ''it's hard to find people with a work ethic.''

headline.main: Where the Motto Is, We Work in Harmony To Ply a Lost Trade

docs.abstract: Profile of Timothy Fink's seven-year-old organ building and repair business based in Port Chester, NY; Fink says labor turnover has to be viewed as an anticipated cost for a small business; photos (Special section: Small Business) (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: LIKE thousands of other business owners around the country, Dwight Messinger got the bad news last fall. As the owner of Power Curbers Inc., a manufacturer of paving equipment in Salisbury, N.C., Mr. Messinger had already seen his company's health insurance premiums jump 25 percent in 2003 while benefits were trimmed. His own wife had been denied reimbursement for a precautionary colonoscopy. Now, shopping desperately for lower prices, Mr. Messinger learned that premiums for his 94 employees would rise another 19 percent this year -- to $749 a month from $634 a month last year.
docs.abstract: Rising cost of health insurance has become No. 1 issue for owners of small businesses; 26 percent of companies with fewer than 200 workers reported rate increases for health insurance of more than 20 percent last year, compared with 20 percent at large companies; only about 47 percent of small companies now offer health insurance, compared with 98 percent at businesses with more than 200 employees on payroll; rising rates confront employers with choice of either absorbing higher costs at time when they cannot raise their prices or alienating employees with cuts in benefits; drawing; graph (Special section: Small Business (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: HEALTH insurance is not the only kind of insurance giving small-business owners fits these days. Over the last three years, workers' compensation premiums have risen by an average of 50 percent nationwide. The increase has been even greater in California, where Gov. Arnold Schwarzenegger has threatened to use a ballot initiative to push proposed caps on medical costs and benefits if budget-reduction legislation is not passed by March.
docs.abstract: Small-business owners say they are straining under workers' compensation premiums, which have risen by average of 50 percent nationwide; one part of problem is growing number of small businesses that evade requirement to carry workers' compensation coverage; their workers can still file claims when injured, but costs are usually passed along to companies with insurance, which pay higher premiums as result (Special section: Small Business) (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: THE hiring spree by Fine Point Technologies in the last six weeks sounds at first like a story from another world, a happy one that existed five years ago. Top executives at the New York City software company recently signed up an outside investor and increased the work force by 25 percent. But the scale of the increase -- from 40 to 50 workers -- and the anxiety that accompanied it make it clear this is no boomtime bubble-chasing.

headline.main: The Big Question: To Grow or Not to Grow?

docs.abstract: Tricky question facing small businesses is whether to expand and take on more employees, and it is trickier still early in economic recovery whose strength is uncertain; interviews with sampling of small businesses indicate that reasons to expand -- or not -- are as varied as companies themselves; photos; graphs show that while 89 percent of American companies have fewer than 20 employees, they employ only 18 percent of nation's workers (Special section: Small Business) (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: IN economic terms, spring may finally be arriving for small business -- a little sooner, it seems, than for corporate America. Because data collection and analysis can take at least a year, there are no hard statistics about the state of small business today, said Chad Moutray, chief economist for the Office of Advocacy of the Small Business Administration.

headline.main: Optimism, and Hiring, Appear to Be on the Rise

docs.abstract: General sense of optimism seems to prevail among small-business owners, one that is far greater than year ago, and many small busineses plan to increase capital spending and investment in inventories and hire more workers as well; graph (Special section: Small Business) (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Paul Krugman says most American are happy with the quality of their health care (column, Feb. 17). But there is a disaster looming: the closing of major public hospitals due to state budget crises and the swelling ranks of the uninsured. In California, where managed care made its earliest mark, such a collapse is imminent in Los Angeles, San Francisco and Oakland.
docs.abstract: Dr Sara Hartley letter comments on Paul Krugman's observation (Feb 17 column) that most Americans are happy with quality of their health care; says that will not remain so after major public hospitals are closed because of state budget crises and swelling ranks of uninsured

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: In ''The Health of Nations'' (column, Feb. 17), Paul Krugman says ''people are happy with the quality of health care, if they can afford it.'' Unfortunately, what makes them happy is killing them. Americans think access to high-tech procedures and expensive specialists translates into better outcomes, but the opposite is true.
docs.abstract: Dr Steven Wilks letter comments on Paul Krugman's Feb 17 column on health care; contends our European counterparts spend less per capita on health care, but live longer and have lower infant mortality rates; contends one reason is that their systems are oriented toward primary care

docs.lead_paragraph: Todd Bradley, PalmOne's president and chief executive, recalls meetings last year with product designers of the company's predecessor, Palm Inc., to work out details of their next line of hand-held computers. With the market taking off for cellphones that could do more than receive calls, while demand shrank for the stand-alone hand-held devices that were their specialty, the executives knew that Palm's future depended on quickly introducing the right product.

headline.main: Palm's Marriage Of Convenience To Handspring Shows Promise

docs.abstract: Palm's acquisition of rival Handspring, completed in October, has helped Palm, renamed PalmOne, move its product line away from calculator-sized 'personal digital assistants' and toward so-called smart phones, mobile phones that have appointment calendars and address books of PDA's but also advanced functions like ability to run spreadsheets, connect to corporate databases, access e-mail messages, download music and take photographs; Handspring, which was founded five years ago by former Palm executives who had helped develop PalmPilot, has been pioneer in high-end market for multipurpose handheld devices; photos of Todd Bradley, president of PalmOne, and of Ed Colligan and Kenneth Wirt, with Treo and Tungsten devices that helped develop (L)

docs.lead_paragraph: It was a small kitchen fire, by the standards of the New York City Fire Department: only a few hoses, out in 15 minutes. No big deal. But to the New York restaurant world, it might as well have been a towering inferno.

headline.main: Chef's Lofty Dream Is Set Back by Fire At Columbus Circle

docs.abstract: Electrical fire knocks Per Se, celebrity chef Thomas Keller's newly opened and ultrahyped Manhattan restaurant, out of business for at least two weeks; restaurant already boasted two-month wait for reservations; photo (M)
docs.snippet: It was a small kitchen fire, by the standards of the New York City Fire Department: only a few hoses, out in 15 minutes. No big deal.    But to the New York restaurant world, it might as well have been a towering inferno.

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: In ''The Health of Nations'' (column, Feb. 17), Paul Krugman says ''companies are becoming increasingly unwilling to offer insurance to their employees.'' I would go further: employers are increasingly unwilling to hire because of the high costs of health insurance.
